# Items {#Items}

When calculating weapons and equipment, it is important to take the correct value and standard price of the equipment of the appropriate level for calculation. This table is necessary for the calculation of both weapons and armor values.

This table is an overview of the values to calculate across the different tiers:

+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+
| animal | standard value | ranged value | great weapon value | standard price | condition |
+:========:+:============:+:=============:+:==============:+:=============:+:========:+
| level 1 | 30 | 23 | 40 | 5000 | 7 |
+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+
| level 2 | 42 | 35 | 52 | 15000 | 10 |
+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+
| level 3 | 48 | 41 | 58 | 30000 | 14 |
+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+
| level 4 | 53 | 46 | 63 | 60000 | 20 |
+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+
| level 5 | -- | -- | \- | -- |
+----------+--------------+---------------+----------------+---------------+----------+

When choosing the right armor and weapons, it is useful to know the <font color="green">[modifiers due to overload](#load level)</font> so that you don't end up going into battle completely overloaded.

## Condition {#Condition}

Condition is a value inherent to weapons and armor it determines both how Helpful they are in battle as well as their sale value.

The reduction of the damage value or armor value.

| condition in percent | damage / armor value reduction by |
|:------------------:|:----------------------------------:|
| \<= 50% | 30% |
| \<= 20% | 50% |
| 0% | item destroyed |

: state

| equipment condition in percent | price in percent of purchase price |
|:------------------------------:|:--------------------------------:|
| 100% | 50% |
| \<100% | 35% |
| \<50% | 15% |

: Equipment selling price

The state can be decreased by either DM's decisions or automatically, and can only be raised again by using material of the appropriate level.

Automatic state decrease occurs when an attack or defense has a <font color="green">[critical fail](#Critical)</font> and the character has a <font color="green">[luck/faith save](#lucksave)</font> fail. If this happened on an attack, the weapon's condition decreases, and on a defense, the armor's condition decreases.

## Weapons {#Weapons}

Weapons come in all sizes and shapes, as long as it is not inappropriate the player can choose.

### Ranged weapons {#Ranged weapons}

Ranged weapons are a necessary asset for any armed group. They allow for quick and good ambushes and give you the opportunity to attack enemies from a safe distance. Furthermore, long-range weapons allow the use of special ammunition - so-called <font color="green">[ammo types](#Ammo)</font> failed

The most important thing when calculating the values of ranged weapons is to work with the special ranged value instead of the standard value. You can use the crossbow with a small shield. Ranged weapons that you can fire while lying or crouching also get a higher sneak modifier, although if you make a sneak attack with a musket you will be spotted right away anyway. Ranged weapons also have initiative advantages, which you can <font color="green">[read about here](#initiative)</font>. All ranged weapons have a parry modifier of 0.2.

These are the ranged weapons you have to choose from as an adventurer:

+---------------------+---------------------+----------------------+---------+-------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+
| Weapon | Damage | Price | Weight | Armor Penetration | Addition |
+:===================:+:===================:+:====================:+:=======:+:=================:+:===============================================================:+
| bow | ranged combat value | standard price | 1 kg | no | no |
+---------------------+---------------------+----------------------+---------+-------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+
| crossbow | ranged value x 1.5 | standard price | 2 kg | no | sneak advantage 4, reload with 50% wsl single action |
+---------------------+---------------------+----------------------+---------+-------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+
| one-handed crossbow | ranged value | standard price x 0.85 | 1 kg | no | Sneak Advantage 4, reload with 50% wsl single action |
+---------------------+---------------------+----------------------+---------+-------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+
| musket | ranged value x 3 | standard price x 2.5 | 5 kg | 90% | Sneak Advantage 4, 1 round reload <br> negates cover tier1 |
+---------------------+---------------------+----------------------+---------+-------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+

Special Features:

-   With the musket, reloading consumes a single and a main action. Evasion is not possible during this process unless you have an action left.
-   All ranged weapons have a throw value of 0.05
-   With a bow, the player gets the chance to attack 2 times in one round, the second attack costs a single action.
-   During a battle, the player has only 10 arrows of special ammunition available in his quiver. When it is completely depleted, a Main action is required to replenish it.
-   The one-handed crossbow has a 50% chance of concealment.

### Large Weapons {#Large Weapons}

A large weapon must always be wielded two-handed. They do more damage than short weapons, but they do not allow a shield. Accordingly, defense must be done with evasion. The exception to this is polearms. Despite this disadvantage, great weapons are incredibly powerful and sometimes allow you to cut your opponent in half with a single blow.

The most important thing when calculating the values of large weapons is to work with the special large weapon value instead of the standard one.

### Pole Weapons {#Pole Weapons}

While polearms are rather average in actual combat against humans, they are absolutely deadly against large enemies, monsters, or from mount. In such a situation, they parry with their normal damage value instead of the parry value and have a damage bonus of 50%. Even when attacked from a mount, polearms get a 50% damage bonus.

## Armor {#Armor}

An armor consists of five parts:

-   A helmet
-   A breastplate
-   A tunic
-   Bracers
-   Greaves

The armor may be composed of any parts of light, medium and heavy armor. The heavier the armor, the more disadvantages it has.

This table shows values for the individual pieces of armor:

Note: donning and doffing refers to a full Light/Medium/Heavy armor.

## potion bags {#potion bags}

Potions are something you want to have available as quickly as possible in battle. That's what the potion bag was designed for. For many soldiers and adventurers, the potion bag is indispensable: to use bombs, power ups and heals easily with a simple action is also a good argument, because this is exactly what the potion bag allows.

There are potion bags with different amounts of slots:

| potion bag | price | slots |
|:-----------:|:-----:|:-----:|
| Small | 2500 | 2 |
| Normal | 7500 | 4 |
| Large | 15000 | 6 |

You can equip one potion per slot.

## Potions {#Potions}

Potions have an effect in combat and outside of combat. The effect outside of combat is specifically determined by the DM based on the level and person involved, but has to follow the described effect in <font color="green">[Drugs and Plants](#DrugsPlants)</font>. How potions are brewed can be read in <font color="green">[Alchemy](#Alchemy)</font>.

The effects in combat can be seen in the table below.

```{r}
dftr=read_xlsx("BookdownData/BookdownGeneralData.xlsx",sheet="PotionBookdown")

dftr %>% relocate(potions,level,effect) %>%
  mutate(
    across(c(effect,addition), ~replace_na(.x, ""))
  ) %>%
  reactable(groupBy = "potions",
            columns = list(
                      Level=colDef(format=colFormat(prefix = "level "),
                                   aggregate = "unique"),
                      Potions = colDef(
                        # Render grouped cells without the row count
                        grouped = JS("function(cellInfo) {
                            return cellInfo.value
                          }"), align="left",
                        
                      ),
                      `price in Reiks`= colDef(format=colFormat(suffix = " Reiks"),
                                               aggregate = "unique",
                                               filterable = FALSE),
                      Effect = colDef(
                        name = "effect / addition",
                        # show species under character names
                        cell = function(value, index) {
                          species <- dftr$addition[index]
                          species = ifelse(!is.na(species), species, "")
                          div(
                            div( value),
                            div(style = list(fontSize = 12), species)
                          )
                        }
                      ),
                      Addition = colDef(show = FALSE)
                      
                      ), bordered = F,
            highlight = T, showPageSizeOptions = T, filterable = T,
            pageSizeOptions = c(5,10, 20, 50),
            defaultPageSize = 20, paginationType = "jump",
            theme= overallThemeReactable, defaultColDef = colDef(
              align = "center"
            ), outlined =T, striped = T)
  
```

### Effects of potions:

-   Poison lasts 3 turns
-   Antipyretics have a Special role for Animali, in warmer areas they need them - Depending on Mutation, to avoid Negative Modifiers due to heat. Also they need stronger antipyretics (level 4) to counter goblins heat vision.
-   Madnika: additionally no stamina debuffs/resist 1x fainting due to stamina loss
-   Light of the Allgod: especially effective against Awakened.

## Instruments

With instruments, as with weapons and armor, the character is largely free to choose the look and sound of his instrument, as long as it is not inappropriate. How instruments work in Orbis Aestea <font color="green">[can be found here](#InstrumentsRules)</font>. Each instrument costs 5000 reiks, although special or ornate instruments may cost extra, here the handle is up to the DM.

Overview of instruments:

```{r}
df =read_xlsx("Container/Data/AllaroundDataStorage.xlsx",sheet="Musiksys")

df %>% select(genre name, main instrument, accompanying instrument) %>%
  distinct() %>%
  pivot_longer(-genre_name, values_to = "instrument") %>%
  pivot_wider(names_from = name, values_from = genre name) %>%
  rename(main_genre = main instrument , accompaniment_genre = accompaniment instrument) %>%
  knitr::kable()

```

## trap

Everyone knows that preparation is the key to success and nothing supports this principle more than a well set trap. Traps exist in many colors and shapes but they all have one thing in common - the enemy who falls into them is easy prey.

Traps offer a great advantage, but only if they remain undetected by the victim until triggered. In this sense, traps can be detected by a Perception check. But even if the traps remain undetected - either by camouflage or by simply being overlooked in the heat of the moment - the victim still has a chance to make a suitable defense check, provided that an initiative roll was successful.

![](Pictures/Rules/Fallenfunkt.png)

### Typical traps

#### Bear Trap {.unnumbered}

A typical reusable trap mostly used for game, two serrated metal jaws that snap together when the pressure plate is triggered and trap a leg of their victim. This not only causes damage to the leg, but severely restricts the victim's mobility and makes it difficult to repel attacks.

+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| Characteristic | Expression |
+:============================:+:==========================================================:+
| for building | metal, must be forged |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| interrupt | yes |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| damage | 70 damage on random leg |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| Release | Single + Main action |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| Disatvantage<br>in trap | Disatvantage 3 |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| special features | immobility, placement in combat (main action if to hand) |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| disarming | main action |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+
| weight | 7 kg |
+------------------------------+------------------------------------------------------------+

#### snare trap {.unnumbered}

A sneaky trap that requires little material but a lot of time to set up. When triggered, the victim is pulled upwards into the air and dangles freely. The heavier the armor the harder it is to break free due to the lower mobility. To set up the snare trap, you have to reach a threshold of three in a craft or survival test.

+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| Characteristic | Expression |
+:===============================:+:=======================================================:+
| material needed<br> to build | rope + counterweight |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| interrupt | Yes |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| damage | no |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| Liberation | Main Action <br>Throw against weight-based Threshold |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| Disatvantage<br>in the trap | Disatvantage 4 |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| special features | immobility |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| Disatvantage | Single Action |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+
| Weight | 0.5 Kg |
+---------------------------------+---------------------------------------------------------+

The check for the release is thrown with Acrobatics. For classification, the <font color="green">[load levels](#load level)</font> apply here

The Thresholds are:

-   For light load: 2

-   For medium load: 3

-   With heavy load: 5

-   In case of extrication: Main Action of the other person (cut the rope)

#### Trip Trap {.unnumbered}

The simplest of all traps, a simple taut rope at ankle height, whether tied tightly or fastened at two points with nails or other means.

+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| characteristic | expression |
+:===============================:+:=======================================:+
| material needed<br> to build | rope |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| interrupt | yes |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| damage | No |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| Release | Unnecessary, Stand up costs single Action |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| Disatvantage<br>in trap | Disatvantage 3 to get up |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| special features | person falls down |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| disatvantage | single action |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+
| Weight | 0.5 Kg |
+---------------------------------+-----------------------------------------+

#### crow's feet {.unnumbered}

The trap which is the easiest to place in combat and the only one that provides advantage even after it is discovered. At the same time, the advantage decreases with increasing armor.

+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Characteristic | Expression |
+:===============================:+:=================================================================================================================:+
| material needed<br> to build | metal, must be forged |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| interrupt | only to medium armor |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| damage | no, unless you fall |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| release | removal from foot costs single action |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Disatvantage<br>in the trap | Disatvantage 2 - AoE |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Special features | placing with single action possible at any time<br>Heavy armor ignores trap<br> picking up with Luck possible |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| disarming | no |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| weight | 1 Kg |
+---------------------------------+-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+

#### Alternative Traps {.unnumbered}

This category includes all traps that are not mentioned in "Typical Traps", these are mostly situation and history dependent therefore the regulation is also left to the DM. Examples would be, rolling balls or swinging tree trunks.

```{r}
dfag=read_xlsx("Container/Data/MiscItemList.xlsx",sheet="All Items")


dfag %>% select("Category", "Item", "Price", "Weight", "Merchant", "Description") %>%

                        substring(dealer,1, nchar(dealer)-1))) %>%
  relocate(category, item, description, weight, price) %>%
  arrange(category) %>%
  reactable(groupBy = "category",
            columns = list(

              Price = colDef(format=colFormat(suffix = " Reiks"),

            pageSizeOptions = c(5,10, 20, 50),
            defaultPageSize = 20, paginationType = "jump",
            theme= overallThemeReactable, defaultColDef = colDef(
              align = "center"
            ), outlined = T,
            striped=T, resizable = T)


```
